thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: $A rebounds above 70 US cents

title: $A rebounds above 70 US cents
text:
Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 6:13 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A rebounds above 70 US cents AAP – 44 minutes ago Print 
Higher commodity prices and a burst of optimism on world share markets has pushed the Australian dollar back above 70 US cents. 
At 1700 AEST on Wednesday, the local unit was trading at 70.49 US cents, up from 69.73 cents on Tuesday. 
Prices for iron ore, copper and oil all rose, lifting sentiment for commodity-based currencies like the Australian dollar, Westpac economists said in a note to clients. 
That combined with a strong bout of optimism on world equity markets, including a two per cent gain for local shares. 
Wall Street rose more than two per cent on Tuesday and European markets gained more than one per cent, as Shanghai's volatile market showed signs of stability. 
"The Australian dollar was a strong outperformer, and the rally in emerging market currencies highlights the risk-on tone," National Australia Bank senior currency strategist Emma Lawson said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 84.98 Japanese yen, up from Tuesday's close of 82.58 yen, and at 63.20 euro cents, up from 62.25 euro cents. 
But the local currency's resurgence may not continue, with concerns about China's weakening economy still a factor, said OANDA Australia and Asia Pacific senior trader Stephen Innes. 
"I suspect the Aussie bounce will be short lived as the currency is still in the weeds with China's economic woes which will continue to dominate global sentiment." 
Greater risk sentiment sent the Australian bond market lower. 
At 1630 AEST on Wednesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.233 (implying a yield of 2.767 per cent), down from 97.305 (2.695 per cent) on Tuesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.135 (1.865 per cent), down from 98.200 (1.800 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Hockey blames world woes for gloomy data AAP
